body:
@pivotal-jbarrett the overwhelming majority of commenters both in this PR and on the dev list approved.  Your request to fix the entire world as part of this PR also sets a bad precedent.  See item #3 in https://medium.freecodecamp.org/unlearning-toxic-behaviors-in-a-code-review-culture-b7c295452a3c
I don't disagree with any of the next steps you proposed, only with requiring them as part of this PR.

@onichols-pivotal I don’t see how shutting down a legitimate concern that this PR violates a strongly held principle that a PR should not knowingly result in a failed CI is appropriate. My request for failures to be addressed prior to merging is not a “while your are at it” sort of request. Any other PR that results in a failure would be rejected, so should this one. I am all for reducing toxic culture but this card needs to be played appropriately. Used in a context like this I feel it undermines our efforts.

If you feel strongly that this PR did not warrant the need to pass CI, or otherwise addressing a reviewers changes, you should have follow up with that reviewer to get the approval. Setting a precedent of ignoring concerns of committer is more toxic. It sends the message that if your disapproval of a commit is not shared by the author it can just be ignore without further discussion so why bother speaking up. Especially so in a situation where the reviewer is attempting to uphold our principles of development.

Furthermore, while the content of the PR was approved I don’t feel the merge itself was. Others raised questions about the significantly increase time and stability issues. I see no reason to race to commit such an change without fully addressing those concerns. 

If you feel like a conversation around the use of toxic language and how to police it needs to happen I would gladly have that discussion on the dev list.
I’m mostly indifferent, though I lean to the side of not trying to hack around concourse odd layouts. I hear there are some improvements in this area coming in the not too distant future.

I did not knowingly or in fact violate this strongly-held principal.  My test pipeline was all green before merging, and at this moment the main pipeline is also all green.  

The time the Windows tests take has been clearly communicated from the outset, and has not changed (other than now they start and finish 2 hours sooner than before).  Like you, I look forward to seeing us iterate on understanding and improving those times, now that they are more visible.

I apologize for rushing to get this merged before confirming with you that your concerns had been handled.  I misjudged that they had been satisfactorily ameliorated. I am willing to revert until everything is settled to your satisfaction (or you can feel free to revert).

I admit I am confused on what you are measuring when you talk about a "feedback cycle".  The defect fixed by this PR was that we were silently treating a third of our test failures as green for the purpose of publishing the latest stable SHA.  False negatives destroy confidence in the entire pipeline, so fixing as soon as possible (once we established that the tests were indeed testing a supported feature of Geode) seems not unreasonable, and getting it in before the weekend gives a chance to monitor (and revert if anything is not as expected).  As far as developer feedback, this PR made no changes to the PR pipeline, and still offers developers all the same feedback that was available in the main pipeline before (with fewer clicks and 2 hours faster).  If a developer makes a change that breaks only on Windows, in fact now they will get that feedback approximately 2 weeks faster than before (yes, it really did take that long to notice some breakages earlier this month).  I acknowledge that work related to the hidden job Benchmarks will now have a longer feedback cycle.  If it is in active development it might make sense to spin up a feature pipeline that omits most long-running test jobs...and we should probably try to avoid hidden jobs in the main pipeline anyway...
I'm also fairly indifferent to the tall pipeline view, especially since it won't be an issue once we remove JDK11 jobs.  As long as I can see red when it happens, I'm happy :).
@mcmellawatt no plans to remove JDK11 or any other jobs
@Petahhh
Consensus is keep the natural layout, even if it is tall.

> @mcmellawatt no plans to remove JDK11 or any other jobs

Oops I meant remove JDK8 jobs, but I guess we won't be removing those either.
@Petahhh @jmelchio
NoRouteToHostException and PortUnreachableException shouldn't be thrown by bind() operations, which is what we're doing in this code.
@Petahhh @jmelchio @jackw26
@jinmeiliao @jdeppe-pivotal @onichols-pivotal

Hello

I see that "concourse-ci/UpgradeTestOpenJDK11 " check has failed earlier and now with an empty commit, it is in pending state. This check has nothing to do with my changes. Please review.
@Petahhh @jmelchio @jack26

@onichols-pivotal This is a merge of master to develop, which should be a fast-forward in all cases, but isn't due to this step missing in our release notes. Our confluence document is incomplete regarding the merge steps for a release. [https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/comparing-workflows/gitflow-workflow](https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/comparing-workflows/gitflow-workflow)
I would like to see a thumbs-up from @pivotal-jbarrett regarding the benchmarks stuff, and steps added to the release process wiki for performing this step after each future release

I don't fully understand the logic for merging all changes from master to develop.  fixes of course should always be brought forward to develop too, but generally they are cherry-picked from develop to begin with.  Other release-specific changes are made on the release branch that are never intended to come back to develop, such as removing -SNAPSHOT in gradle.properties, etc.  Am I understanding that you want to change the process to bring all of these release customizations back into develop?
@upthewaterspout I pruned the files and re-pushed

@onichols-pivotal As part of the merge back to develop, the 'breaking' changes like versioning are left behind in the merge/conflict resolution stage. The point of merging releases into master, is that master is then a record of all releases. The point of merging releases (including hotfixes) back into develop, is that your project has confidence that all patches have been brought forward.

> the 'breaking' changes like versioning are left behind in the merge/conflict resolution stage

this sound like a manual, non-automated process.  I am confused since earlier you said

> should be a fast-forward in all cases
@onichols-pivotal 'should be' in the general case for projects, perhaps not for our use of semver and client/server compatibility tokens.
@dschneider-pivotal any concerns with merging these changes?
Thanks for advice.
thanks for pointing that out! Im changing it...
I have added a new pull request with the requested changes.
@metatype commented (on dev list) "I don’t agree that adding the exception class name creates a better user experience."
Merging into develop, without squash or rebase. This is to preserve the history between release, master, and develop, according to the Gitflow workflow.
@jackw26 @Petahhh @jmelchio

@jhuynh1 yes, usually we would see that a server that went off cpu would be kicked out by other members.  In some rare cases we've seen such a server initiate suspect processing on all other members and succeed in kicking them out, causing the whole cluster to melt down.  This change helps to prevent that from happening.

> Great work, Mario - you addressed the JIRA ticket exactly as intended.
> On review, I found that as a reader, I wanted to see the link to the quick reference table on the content page, not in just the left-hand navigation pane, so I went ahead and reinstated that link.
> Thank you for your contribution.

Yes I agree, it is a much better with this link on content page.  
Thank you all for approving changes. :)
@Petahhh @jmelchio @jackw26
The single test failure is [GEODE-6645](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-6645).
As this changes are approved, can you merge it? Thanks!
@jmelchio @Petahhh
@Petahhh @jmelchio @jackw26
@Petahhh @jmelchio @jackw26
please `./gradew spA`
This PR appears to have been abandoned.  It will be closed in 72 hours if there is no further activity.
Could you just clarify, do you have any additional info about the problem. Thanks.
@mivanac I so sorry. When I reviewed this on my phone yesterday I read it all backwards. You removed the poisoning line from the existing test. All is well.
it would also be nice to add a Benchmarks `group` that shows only Build, the jobs that are gating for benchmarks, and Benchmarks.  It's really hard to see it clearly in the `complete` view.

> it would also be nice to add a Benchmarks `group` that shows only Build, the jobs that are gating for benchmarks, and Benchmarks. It's really hard to see it clearly in the `complete` view.

This might be a useful change to the pipeline, but it isn't part of the issue being addressed here. If you would like to see it done, please submit an issue!
Sorry for pushing changes with --force, I read the discussion in the list. Next time I will just push a new commit with changes
Should I remove `init()` and `close()` too?
Note to any reviewers: We are submitting a separate PR to address the warnings in this file. We wanted to keep the synch fixes separated for ease of testing & reviewing.
@jmelchio are you saying this is the warnings cleanup submission? If so can you update the title to reflect that?

@pivotal-jbarrett no, just wanted to ensure that we understand that there are fixes to be made to address warnings in the file but that those will be submitted in a separate pull request under `GEODE-6855`
It appears the consensus is that we are in favor of introducing time units to the public API and deprecating the ambiguous value only methods.

Only in this case, it probably does offer more information if the message itself has typo's that doesn't make any sense. Another way to fix this is to check if the message itself has "nor servname" string, if so, give it another message that makes sense.
@Petahhh @jmelchio
Yes, remove all the native methods.

At some point I think this class could be redesigned and it would just be LinuxStatHelper.
isLinux was being used by some code that I think now only needs to call PureJavaMode.osStatsAreAvailable(). I think PureJavaMode also needs to be cleaned up since that is the only mode we now support (geode never has the native library that used to make use not pure).
For this pr I would just focus on cleaning up HostStatHelper as much as you can and save the other cleanup for other prs.

@upthewaterspout I think the only feature we're still using in Attach API that isn't available elsewhere is the check `isProcessAlive(int pid)` for any pid (not a `java.lang.Process` forked from the current JVM). I'm all for removing it. EDIT: actually NativeCalls (JNA) does have support for it.
Maybe:  `ProcessHandle.of(pid).ifExists(ProcessHandle::isAlive)`
This needs at least one ASF committer approval to get merged. @moleske @kirklund please review.
@moleske @upthewaterspout I filed [GEODE-6841: Remove dependency on Attach API](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-6841)

> Maybe: ProcessHandle.of(pid).ifExists(ProcessHandle::isAlive)

@metatype What API is ProcessHandle part of? My IntelliJ project cannot find that class. Also, please update https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-6841 with any info on alternative APIs. Please provide a review as well (we need 3) -- thanks! EDIT: Looks like `ProcessHandle` isn't added until JDK 9 source level.

> Are you still working on other commits or are you ready for a full review?

Yes, I have just fixed the wrong test name I detected and added the `@Rule` you suggested, thanks.

My only concern is if the HostStatHelper UT is enough for this PR. With the refactor I think the more important part of its behaviour is covered, anyway.

I might be archaic in my thinking or understanding, but I thought there was some guidance that was once provided that inherited Test classes were a smell. If so, I do see quite a few of the test classes use inheritance, which makes this review harder, as I would now have to go back to source code to understand what a specific method would be providing.
In addition, I also see some classes are names "*Integration*". I thought there was an integration category that was used. Maybe the category was missed or maybe renaming of the Test class to further its classification would be more helpful.
Overall, these changes look good, with only cosmetic and hopefully minor changes
The test failure seems legit.
@Petahhh @jmelchio @jackw26 @sabbeyPivotal

@kohlmu-pivotal If I have a class called LocatorLauncher, then I create a unit test in src/test called LocatorLauncherTest and an integration test in src/integrationTest called LocatorLauncherIntegrationTest. I use those names simply because I want to. That's what I documented on the Geode wiki in the past and have been using for years.

@bschuchardt The diff for DistributedSystemIntegrationTest is 4th commit down in the commits tab. Here's a URL to it: https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3650/commits/e3d8cfb6e91322dd1ae612195bd3bc12e845f98a

@kohlmu-pivotal Re: inherited test classes: These are not new tests that I just recently decided to create with multiple-class inheritance. I simply cleaned them up. I'm not going to rewrite them from scratch, but you certainly can if you really want to.
I see now there is an existing DataSerializer method for serializing ConcurrentHashMap, so I can just use that rather than doing my own snapshot-before-serialization logic in CqNameToOpHashMap.

I made a change so that the disk store creation `gfsh` commands now also check that the command `doesNotContainOutput("Did not complete waiting")`. I think this effectively serves the same purpose that you were suggesting.
Going to merge this without review because it is a simple logging change.
closed due to inactivity

@dschneider-pivotal the problem I really have with the disable flag is that it’s not consistent. It’s not used for every statistics. If we made it consistent such that the stats service itself checked it that would be consistent or removing it completely would also be consistent.

@pivotal-jbarrett I think it is consistent but I might be missing something. When the InternalDistributedSystem creates the StatisticsManager singleton it passes the disabled flag in. If they are disabled then every Statistics instance created by that manager is a dummy. Given that, I was wondering why FunctionStats has its own dummy. It could have just created one like normal and it would have been a dummy. I think the reason was so it could have a single dummy instance instead of one for every named function. If you look at InternalDistributedSystem.getFunctionStats(String) it would have to look up the dummy each time in a concurrentMap. So it saves this concurrent map lookup when stats are disabled. 
Do you know of places that are directly creating their Statistics instead of using the StatisticsManager on InternalDistributedSystem? If such places exist then they would be inconsistent.

The PR is split in two commits:
  - The [first one](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3688/commits/0b4cd5b410e0a6a99bf5970ebd905e7fee279885) reverts some changes made to test classes when we deleted the `TypedJson` class and moved to jackson; and adds several tests to make sure we retain backward compatibility.
  - The [second one](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3688/commits/0d7eaaae9bc52a8ab2ea5cf50d030314a051f9f0?file-filters%5B%5D=&owned-by%5B%5D=) contains the actual changes to fix the JIRA ticket and restore backward compatibility.
note that the namesake work of this PR already got merged as https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3659 so this PR is now just "above and beyond" cleanup

I have realized I have to change this code, or Geode will not be able to work on Windows.
With this code, an exception will be thrown whenever the `HostStatHelper` class is loaded, and the OS is not linux, which is not the expected behaviour.
@jdeppe-pivotal @onichols-pivotal @jinmeiliao @jackw26
@Petahhh @jmelchio @jackw26
@PurelyApplied  can you review this?
My approval pertains primarily to the JMX code changes. It would be good to get reviews by some devs with better knowledge of DiskStoreImpl and related internals.

@jinmeiliao What qualifies as "more sensible"?  If we are not going to print the exception's message, then we lose the information about exactly what hostname was not found...

Do any of these look better?

#1 (generic)
`Connecting to Locator at [host=l192.168.99.1, port=12345] ..`
`Unable to connect.`

#2 (Safari)
`Connecting to Locator at [host=l192.168.99.1, port=12345] ..`
`Can't find the server.`

#3 (golang)
`Connecting to Locator at [host=l192.168.99.1, port=12345] ..`
`dial tcp l192.168.99.1:12345: i/o timeout`

#4 (Chrome)
`Connecting to Locator at [host=l192.168.99.1, port=12345] ..`
`Locator can't be reached.  Server or IP address could not be found.`

#5 (Firefox)
`Connecting to Locator at [host=l192.168.99.1, port=12345] ..`
`The proxy server is refusing connections.`

#6 (Zero Wing)
`Connecting to Locator at [host=l192.168.99.1, port=12345] ..`
`All your server are belong to us.`

#7 (2001 A Space Odyssey)
`Connecting to Locator at [host=l192.168.99.1, port=12345] ..`
`I'm sorry, Dave. I'm afraid I can't do that.`
@Petahhh @jmelchio @jackw26
I implemented the change you suggested @kirklund and fixed up a few other log function calls while I was at it.

Hey @moleske,

I generally do the same with all my PRs: cleanup every single warning and "smelly" code I see while fixing the actual bug for which the ticket was opened. For this particular one, however, I didn't even consider doing it, basically because I would need to spend way more time cleaning up minor stuff than actually fixing the problem...  I've also heard that we're not investing much effort on `Pulse` anymore and the idea is to replace it completely in the near future, so I honestly saw no point in cleaning the entire class, just cleaned up the method I had to fix.
But yeah, I agree with you in that we should clean and improve the source code we touch 👍 .
Cheers.
I was wondering about the same thing as @jujoramos , maybe the numOfJMXConnections should be a thread local?

PR has been updated to revert the first approach and go with option #4 instead.  Now the user will see:
`Connecting to Locator at [host=l192.168.99.1, port=52326] ..`
`JMX manager can't be reached. Hostname or IP address could not be found.`
I have generally been steering clear of tests in the cleanup. This could be a nasty rabbit hole to go down. I suggest staying focused on the production code for now.

I tested with [#3537](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3537) and this will be fixed with that changes. After merging PR [#3537](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3537) to develop branch I will close this PR and reference the ticket to [GEODE-6822](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-6822) as duplicated.
Sorry, I made a mistake while pushing new commit. I will close this and open new PR. Sorry again for spam.
@jujoramos and @jinmeiliao, please review changes. This is new PR related to [#3677](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3677). Thanks in advance!

After discussions with Dan and Barry, we decided that they best way to optimize this check is to not do the check. Currently the action taken by the check causes data inconsistency. So I'm going to close this pull request and submit another one that removes the check.

> This PR doesn't actually fix the root issue of GEODE-6834, right? That would require changing PRHARedundancyProvider to not read any values from prStats. So, I assume this would be a temporary improvement to get past any issues caused by redundancy provider not working properly when one of the int stats read by PRHARedundancyProvider wraps to zero?

This PR does fix GEODE-6834. The problem being fixed is that some of the stats on PartionedRegionStats were 32-bit ints which could wrap around when doing local operation and cause the value of the statistic when it is displayed to be hard to understand. So this PR addressed that by changing those stats to be 64-bit longs.
While working on it we found that the redundancy provider was reading stats from PartitionedRegionStats. Features are not supposed to do this but should instead maintain their own counter. Since stats can be disabled (and when read disabled always return 0) having product feature depend on stats is a bad idea. We filed a new ticket: GEODE-6849 but this PR does not fix GEODE-6849.

Hey @agingade,

Thanks for reviewing this PR!. I didn't remove the `CollectionSerializer`, BTW, just moved the definition down in the class, it now starts around line [282]( https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3688/commits/0d7eaaae9bc52a8ab2ea5cf50d030314a051f9f0#diff-fce0641932c105e812f0d7859f2c587cR282.). Is that what you were looking for?.
@kirklund and @PurelyApplied can you merge this revert? It turns out my fix busts the pipeline.
@dschneider-pivotal the failed distributed tests seem legit.

Last commit includes the following changes:
* Rename `HostStatHelper` to `OsStatisticsProvider` and transform it into an instance based object class.
* Change all calls to `PureJavaMode.osStatsAreAvailable` by `OsStatisticsProvider.osStatsSupported`.
* Remove `osStatsAreAvailable` from `PureJavaMode`.
* Now `OsStatisticsProvider` uses `SystemUtils`.
* Use `assertThat` instead of `assertTrue` in tests.
@Petahhh @jackw26 @jmelchio

Sounds great for develop.

Just looking at the diff, I can't quite picture what the changes will look like for a release pipeline.  I like that you removed the conditionals that suppressed UpdatePassingRef from appearing in release pipelines, thank you!  We should never have conditionalized those at all, and I am glad to see the simplifications!  Are there any further conditionals that could be removed as well?

Also, can you please comment whether you tested these changes in a release-branch context or only in a develop context?
This work was done on the wrong code base. I'm closing this pr and will resubmit.
